Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Foundations for Heterogeneous Datacenter Design and Deployment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the past 45 years, computer scientists and engineers have transformed plentiful transistors into computational capability. At present, energy costs jeopardize further capability scaling, especially in datacenters. Given constrained datacenter power budgets, which are already at megawatt scales, this project is developing new paradigms to design and deploy heterogeneous datacenter architectures to improve energy efficiency by an order of magnitude. Heterogeneity specializes hardware for particular applications and deploys a mix of hardware for a mix of application needs. Specialization improves efficiency as overheads from supporting general, arbitrary computation are reduced. To realize heterogeneous efficiency, this project is rethinking design and deployment. Rethinking design to reduce specialization costs, this project is parameterizing hardware designs to facilitate their re-use, applying statistical inference to explore design spaces, and clustering applications that have similar hardware needs to increase each design?s market volume. Rethinking deployment to reduce performance risk, this project is developing multi-agent systems that transparently manage and allocate heterogeneous resources to meet performance targets.

This project has the potential to impact the composition and management of datacenters that underpin cloud computing. As access to cloud computing is democratized, diverse users will seek computation. And this project is architecting energy-efficient infrastructure to provide that computation. The design and deployment of heterogeneous architectures requires a holistic view of computer systems. The project is integrating research with curricular development, broadening students? views of processor, memory, network, and storage. The project is engaging all students at all levels of education and from all backgrounds, preparing future generations for computer engineering and research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. The research supported by this award has laid the foundations for heterogeneous datacenter design and deployment. The PI and his students have made several key contributions. 

First, the PI made the case for using dynamic random access memories (DRAMs) originally designed for mobile systems, such as phones, in high-performance datacenter servers. Mobile-class memory addressed the energy efficiency challenges of server-class memory by forgoing more expensive interface circuitry. The PI and his team designed server memory systems that use mobile-class memory, showing that search engines and memory caches can tolerate its reduced data rates and benefit from its energy efficiency. Moreover, the PI designed a disintegrated memory controller that connects multiple memory technologies and command protocols, such as dynamic random access memory and phase change memory, to a single processor. Together, these studies allowed datacenters to exploit new and unconvential memory technologies. 

Second, the PI designed mechanisms to allocate heterogeneous hardware resources. Because energy-efficient processors and memories may provide insufficient performance for some datacenter workloads and tasks, datacenters must deploy high-performance components as well. The PI and his team proposed economic mechanisms and markets to allocate heterogeneous bundles of hardware to meet software workloads' performance goals. Diverse software workloads bids for heterogeneous hardware bundles. On behalf of human users, proxies profiled hardware-software interactions, inferred preferences for heterogeneous hardware, and translated preferences into bids. This market mechanism was demonstrated for the allocation of heterogeneous processors. 

Third, the PI designed mechanisms to allocate hardware resources fairly. Shared datacenters and servers are energy-efficient but users require incentives to share. The PI and his team developed new approaches to the fair, coordinated allocation of multiple resources in a chip multiprocessor. Allocations ensure sharing incentives, which means that users perform no worse than under equal division, envy-freeness, which means that users prefer their own allocations over others, Pareto-efficiency, which means that no allocation improves performance without harming a user, and strategy-proofness, which means that users can misreport their preferences for resources. The team demonstrateed the mechanism for allocating cache capacity and memory bandwidth in multiprocessor systems.

Fourth, the PI designed mechanisms to allocate shared datacenter power. Datacenters often deploy more servers than they can fully power so that the system fully utilizes provisioned power supplies. The team developed a game-theoretic framework to determine which processors in the datacenter should draw extra power while ensuring that the system does not oversubscribe the shared power supply. The team found an equilibrium in this "computational sprinting game." This equilibrium permitted processors to draw power strategically and independently, permitted the system to efficiently deploy power to improve performance, and permitted the system to avoid tripping the circuit breaker.

Finally, many of these strategies and outcomes have laid the foundations for work in other distributed systems. In future, the PI and his team will extend their research into collaborative computing for distributed, embedded devices. In this setting, nodes are highly heterogeneous. They differ in processing capability, communication capability, and battery capacity. Determining the most effective assignment of tasks to achieve a shared computational goal remains an open challenge. 

Broader Outcomes. Beyond the specific research accomplishments, the research award supported numerous graduate and undergraduate research assistants. The first three graduate students to complete their PhDs under this grant were women, which highlights the importance of training the next generation of leaders and drawing talent from diverse backgrounds. Many of the undergraduate researchers from this project have continued to pursue graduate degrees at schools such as the California Institute of Technology, University of California, Harvard University, Princeton University, University of Texas, and the University of Virginia.
